Fine-grained [[sand]]]]In [[transport engineering]], '''subgrade''' is the native material underneath a constructed road,<ref name="idiot">http://www.highwaysmaintenance.com/drainage.htm The Idiots' Guide to Highways Maintenance ''highwaysmaintenence.com''</ref> pavement or railway (US: railroad) track. It is also called '''formation level'''. The term can also refer to imported material that has been used to build an [[Embankment (transportation)|embankment]]. ==Construction== Subgrades are commonly compacted before the construction of a road, pavement or railway track, and are sometimes stabilized by the addition of [[asphalt]], [[Lime (material)|lime]], [[portland cement]] or other modifiers. The subgrade is the foundation of the pavement structure, on which the [[subbase (pavement)|subbase]] is laid. Preparation of the subgrade for construction usually involves digging, in order to remove surface vegetation, [[topsoil]] and other unwanted material, and to create space for the upper layer of the pavement. This process is known as "subgrade formation" or "reduction to level". The load-bearing strength of subgrade is measured by [[California Bearing Ratio]] (CBR) test, [[falling weight deflectometer]] [[backcalculation]]s and other methods. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Road transport]] [[Category:Pavements]] [[Category:Transport engineering]] [[Category:Permanent way]]
